Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support for students to participate in the Fifteenth Summer School on Exotic Beam (EBSS) Physics at the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory, July 17 - 24, 2016. The school is designed for graduate students, senior undergraduate students who are actively involved in research and postdocs (within 2 years of their degree). The school will consist of morning lectures and hands-on activities in the afternoons. Students will also have an opportunity to present their research. The aim of the summer school is to educate the next generation of scientists that will drive the research at the Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB) when it comes online and other existing rare isotope facilities. In years to come, substantial progress in low-energy nuclear physics will have a broad impact on society, ranging from our understanding of the origin of the elements to the enhancement of national security.

Previous sessions of these summer schools have had broad participation of under-represented minorities, with slightly more than 40% of the participants of the Fourteenth EBSS being female. The organizers of the Fifteenth EBSS will continue the use of accepted best practices to increase diversity and have an inclusive summer school.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report: Fifteenth Exotic Beam Summer School

 

The study of unstable nuclei that have unusual ratios of protons to neutrons is one of the frontiers of nuclear science. The investigation of such exotic nuclei lying far from stability is crucial for understanding the synthesis of nuclei in stellar environment as well as the nature of the nuclear forces that bind atomic nuclei together. The science progress is driven by the development of exotic beams produced in present and next-generation rare-isotope facilities including Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB) which is currently under construction on the campus of Michigan State University.

Nuclear Physics is a very broad and diverse subject, influencing our knowledge on subjects as diverse as halo nuclei at drip lines, many-body quantum theory, the super heavy elements, and the inner structure of neutron stars. There are also a number of applications based on nuclear science and technologies, such as medical diagnostics, material science, and homeland security. The Exotic Beam Summer School 2016 (EBSS2016), which was the fifteenth installment of EBSS series, was held during July 17-24, 2016 to educate and train a next-generation of scientists that drive science with rare-isotope beams at existing and future facilities. The school EBSS2016 was hosted by the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory, Michigan State University.

The fifteenth Exotic Beam Summer School (EBSS2016) was jointly organized by Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Lawrence Berkely National Laboratory, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Argonne National Laboratory, the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory at Michigan State University, and ARUNA. Currently, ARUNA consists of nuclear accelerator laboratories at Florida State University, Ohio University, Texas A&M University, Kentucky University, University of Notre Dame, University of Washington, Hope College, Union College, University of Massachusetts-Lowell, and Triangle University Nuclear Laboratory. The school is funded by these institutions, as well as the US National Science Foundation and Department of Energy. In EBSS2016, 40 participants of graduate students attended the school and received two types of training:

1. During the mornings, they received lectures given by experts in the fields of exotic beam physics. These lectures focuses on experimental and theoretical aspects of nuclear physics as well as interdiciplinary subjects such as nuclear astrophysics and medical applications.

2. During the afternoons, students participated in a variety of hands-on activities, which dealt with specific techniques and tools used in the field of exotic beam physics experiments and various applications.

As a unique feature of this summer school series, the combination of lectures and hands-on activities allows students to apply what they learned immediately in practice.

Besides, the participants in the school also presented their own research to their peers and the lecturers in the poster session and studnets seminar. The interaction between the students and the expert from diverse background is an important component of the program.

In 2008, the United States Department of Energy approved the design and construction of the new National User Facility for Rare Isotope BEams (FRIB) at Michigan State University. FRIB will provide beams of exotic nuclei with unmatched intensities, exceeding what is available today by orders of magnitude. Intense beams available at FRIB facilitate a wide variety of studies in nuclear structure and dynamics, astrophysics, fundamental symmetries, and societal applications. There is a large community of scientists intersted in working with rare-isotope beams; for example, the FRIB User Organization currenly has over 1,300 members and is growing. In order for FRIB to be successful, when it starts operation, there must be a workworce trained in both the physics of exotic beams and in the practical techniques of carrying out an experiment. This summer school series is designed to specifically address this need - to ensure that a new generation of scientists from a broard range of institutions and background, is trained, motivated, and equiped to push the field forward to new and important breakthroughs.

The school web site is available online at https://people.nscl.msu.edu/~iwasaki/ebss2016.html with a link top lecture slides presented during the summer school.
